content.title: Ventilator Weaning and Liberation
content.summary: Ventilator weaning is the process of transitioning patients from mechanical ventilation to spontaneous breathing. It involves daily screening for readiness, spontaneous breathing trials (SBT), and extubation when criteria are met. Most patients can be extubated after passing a 30-120 minute SBT. Prolonged weaning failure requires identification and treatment of underlying causes.
key_points: Daily readiness screening: resolved/improving cause, adequate oxygenation, hemodynamically stable, awake
Spontaneous Breathing Trial (SBT): T-piece or low PS (5-8 cmH2O) for 30-120 min
Cuff leak test for upper airway patency if concern for edema
Causes of weaning failure: cardiac, respiratory, neuromuscular, psychological
content.statement: Ventilator liberation requires systematic daily screening, spontaneous breathing trials when criteria are met, and extubation following successful SBT, with attention to factors that may cause weaning failure.

explanation.intuition: Think of weaning like training wheels on a bike - you gradually reduce support and test if the patient can breathe independently. The SBT is the 'test ride' where you see if they can manage on their own. If they pass, remove the tube.
explanation.key_insight: The longer patients stay on the ventilator, the worse outcomes. Daily awakening trials + SBT (ABC trial) reduced ventilator days. Sedation interruption is as important as ventilator weaning.
explanation.technical_details: RSBI = respiratory rate / tidal volume (in liters). <105 breaths/min/L suggests likely success. SBT can be done with T-piece (no support), CPAP 5 cmH2O, or PS 5-8 + PEEP 5. All approaches have similar predictive value.

definitions_glossary.weaning: Process of reducing ventilator support and transitioning to spontaneous breathing
definitions_glossary.SBT: Spontaneous breathing trial; test of ability to breathe independently
definitions_glossary.RSBI: Rapid shallow breathing index (f/Vt); <105 predicts successful weaning
definitions_glossary.extubation_failure: Need for re-intubation within 48-72 hours of extubation
definitions_glossary.cuff_leak_test: Test for upper airway patency; absent leak suggests edema risk
definitions_glossary.prolonged_weaning: Failure of weaning after 3 or more SBT attempts over >7 days
definitions_glossary.daily_awakening_trial: Interruption of sedation to assess neurological status
definitions_glossary.T_piece: Oxygen delivery system disconnected from ventilator for SBT
definitions_glossary.tracheostomy: Surgical airway for prolonged ventilation needs
definitions_glossary.diaphragm_dysfunction: Weakened diaphragm from ventilator-induced diaphragmatic dysfunction
definitions_glossary.unplanned_extubation: Accidental or self-removal of ETT; 50% require re-intubation

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mechanical ventilation can lead to diaphragm atrophy (VIDD), deconditioning, and psychological dependence; systematic weaning minimizes complications

readiness_criteria: Intact cough and airway protective reflexes

SBT_methods.T_piece: Breathing through tube with oxygen but no ventilator support
SBT_methods.low_PS: PS 5-8 cmH2O + PEEP 5 cmH2O; may slightly overestimate success
SBT_methods.duration: 30-120 minutes; shorter if high-risk for failure

success_criteria: No accessory muscle use, diaphoresis, or agitation
failure_criteria: Signs of increased work of breathing

post_SBT_management.passed: Assess for cuff leak if concern → extubate → monitor closely
post_SBT_management.failed: Return to full support → identify cause → retry next day

causes_of_weaning_failure.cardiac: Weaning-induced pulmonary edema; diurese, may need echo
causes_of_weaning_failure.respiratory: Weak muscles, bronchospasm, secretions, upper airway obstruction
causes_of_weaning_failure.psychological: Anxiety, fear; may benefit from reassurance, gradual weaning

definition.@value: The systematic process of reducing ventilator support and transitioning patients to independent spontaneous breathing culminating in extubation

learning_objectives: Screen patients daily for weaning readiness
Conduct and interpret spontaneous breathing trials
Calculate and apply RSBI for weaning prediction
clinical_pearls: RSBI <105 predicts success; >105 predicts failure (but not perfect)
Daily awakening + SBT reduces vent days and mortality (ABC trial)
Cardiac failure is underappreciated cause of weaning failure - get echo/BNP
If failed 3+ SBTs, consider tracheostomy evaluation

citations.authors: Girard TD, Kress JP, Fuchs BD, et al.
citations.title: Efficacy and safety of a paired sedation and ventilator weaning protocol (Awakening and Breathing Controlled trial)

evidence.confidence_rationale: ABC trial and standard weaning protocols
